text:
Alessia Cara has just been named the Best New Artist at the 2018 Grammy Awards, giving her what is perhaps the most highly-coveted trophy, since a musician can only be nominated once. She beat out SZA, Julia Michaels, Khalid and Lil Uzi Vert for the honor.

Coming into tonight, the singer was up for four prizes in her first year at the Grammys—Best New Artist, Song of the Year, Best Short Form Music Video and Best Pop Duo/Group Performance.

She first broke into the mainstream with her debut single “Here,” which took its time reaching its No. 5 peak in America. Not long after that song performed well, her debut full-length Know-It-All was released, and it managed to start inside the top 10 in the U.S. She went on to send another single from the record, “Scars To Your Beautiful,” to the top 10, and her Zedd collaboration “Stay” also broke into the region.

While she is clearly one of the most talented and promising young musicians out there, it is odd that Cara was nominated at all, given the tight restrictions that govern what year artists can be up for this trophy. Since her debut album (the one that made her well-known to the public) was released in November 2015, she should have been eligible for Best New Artist at the 2017 Grammys, where she wasn’t nominated for anything. That controversy was seemingly never addressed by the Academy, though there may be some questions now that she has not only been nominated, but has taken the gold.

While all five names nominated this time around have contributed to popular culture and proven themselves to be incredibly talented individuals, Cara’s win is deserved, and it’s difficult to argue against the Academy’s decision, difficult as it must have been to make.
